Carter's_Chord:
{{Short description|American country music group}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Carter's Chord | image = Carters_chord.jpg | caption = Carter's Chord, June 2010 | image_size = | landscape = yes | alias = | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | years_active = 2006–2011 | label = [[Show Dog-Universal Music]] | website = http://www.carterschord.com/ | past_members = {{hlist|Becky Scott|Emily Fortney|Joanna Ott}} }} '''Carter's Chord''' was an American [[country music]] group composed of sisters Becky Scott, Emily Fortney, and Joanna Ott, all of whom are singer-songwriters and vocalists. They are also the three daughters of Barny and Carter Roberston, both of whom played in [[Waylon Jennings]]' road band The Waylors in the 1970s; Emily Fortney is also married to Marc "Butter" Fortney of [[Trailer Choir]], another country music group. After several years of performing locally, the trio was signed in 2006 to Show Dog Nashville (now [[Show Dog-Universal Music]]), a record label owned by country singer [[Toby Keith]]. Their debut single, "Young Love", reached the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, as did its followup "Different Breed." Both are included on the group's debut album, which was issued to digital retailers in June 2008. ==Biography== Becky, Emily, and Joanna Robertson were raised in a musically inclined household in southern California.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1010236/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Carter's Chord biography |access-date=2008-02-20 |last=Leahey |first=Andrew |work=[[Allmusic]]}} Their parents—keyboardist and producer Barny Robertson, and vocalist Carter Robertson—were both members of [[Waylon Jennings]]' road band The Waylors in the 1970s.{{cite web |url=http://www.bmi.com/news/entry/534761 |title=Carter's Chord Joins BMI |access-date=2008-02-20 |date=April 4, 2007 |work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=1168&t=Holidys_introduces_Carters_Chord_trio |title=Holidays introduces Carter's Chord trio |access-date=2008-02-20 |date=November 30, 2007 |work=Country Standard Time}}{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=1293&t=Carters_Chord_goes_for_adds_on_Young_Love |title=Carter's Chord goes for adds on "Young Love" |access-date=2008-02-20 |date=January 14, 2008 |work=Country Standard Time}} Having performed together at their home from an early age, the three sisters made their recording debut on Jennings' 1998 album ''[[Cowboys, Sisters, Rascals & Dirt]]'', which their father produced. The sisters would also charge for the shows that they performed at home; among the artists who paid to see them at their house included Jennings and members of [[The Crickets]]. Later on, the three sisters moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], where they began honing their singing and songwriting skills. Eventually, they were discovered by [[Toby Keith]]; after the trio held a showcase on February 14, 2006, Keith signed them to his own [[Show Dog Nashville]] label. The group's first release was a recording of the Christmas standard "[[O come, O come, Emmanuel]]", which was placed into rotation on the television network [[Country Music Television|CMT]]. They also recorded the song "Song of Blue" on the soundtrack to the 2008 film ''[[Beer for My Horses (film)|Beer for My Horses]]'', in which Keith starred. "Young Love", their debut single, was released to radio in January 2008, and entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. A second single, "Different Breed", was released to radio in April 2008. In addition, Carter's Chord released its debut album to digital retailers in June 2008.{{Cite web|url=http://www.the9513.com/qa-with-carters-chord-the-exclusive-9513-interview/|title=Interview with Carters Chord|website=The9513.com}} "You Knock Me Out" was released to radio in January 2010 as the trio's third single, but it failed to chart.{{cite web|url=http://roughstock.com/news/2010/01/20037-carters-chord-you-knock-me-out|title=Carter's Chord - "You Knock Me Out"|last=Peacock|first=Bobby|date=January 8, 2010|work=Roughstock|access-date=August 4, 2018}} Their fourth single, "A Little Less Comfortable", was released a year later in January 2011. This song also failed to chart.{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/carters-chord-a-little-less-comfortable/|title=CARTER'S CHORD, 'A LITTLE LESS COMFORTABLE' – SONG SPOTLIGHT|last=Wilkening|first=Matthew|date=January 14, 2011|work=Taste of Country|access-date=August 4, 2018}} ==Personal lives== Joanna married Mark Ott in mid-2009.{{Cite web|url=https://www.divineimages.net/blog|title=BLOG|website=Divineimages.net|access-date=2020-04-24}} Emily married Marc "Butter" Fortney of [[Trailer Choir]], another act on the Show Dog-Universal label, in September 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/09/07/trailer-choir-carters-chord-married/|title=Trailer Choir, Carter's Chord married|last=Richardson|first=Gayle|date=September 7, 2010|work=The Boot|access-date=October 2, 2010}} Becky got engaged to longtime boyfriend, music producer Jeremiah Scott on August 23, 2011, and married him on April 21, 2012.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nashcountrydaily.com/|title=Nash Country Daily|website=[[Nash Country Daily]]|access-date=2020-04-24}}{{cite web|title=Carter's Chord Singer Becky Robertson Weds in Tennessee|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/carters-chord-becky-robertson-married/|publisher=Taste of Country|access-date=August 31, 2012|date=April 30, 2012}} In March 2014, Ott released a solo EP called ''Machinery''.{{Cite web|url=https://theboot.com/joanna-ott-solo-ep-machinery/|title=Carter's Chord Singer Joanna Ott Releases Solo EP|first=Hannahlee|last=Allers|website=Theboot.com|access-date=2020-04-24}} ==Discography== ===Extended plays=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:10em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! colspan="2"| Peak chart

Director |- | 2008 ! scope="row"| "Different Breed" | Ryan Stadlman |- | 2011 ! scope="row"| "A Little Less Comfortable" | Kristin Barlowe |- | 2012 ! scope="row"| "Love a Little Bigger" | [[Chris Hicky]]{{cite news|title=Carter's Chord, 'Love a Little Bigger' Video Premiere|url=http://www.theboot.com/2012/04/16/carters-chord-love-a-little-bigger-video/|access-date=April 17, 2012|newspaper=The Boot|date=April 16, 2012}} |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Carter's Chord}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Country music groups from Tennessee]] [[Category:Sibling musical trios]] [[Category:Musical groups from Nashville, Tennessee]] [[Category:Vocal trios]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 2006]] [[Category:Show Dog-Universal Music artists]]
